title: AB 1546
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The State Registrar is responsible for organizing and preserving certificates and maintaining confidential birth, death, and marriage record indices exempt from disclosure under the California Public Records Act. The State Registrar may release comprehensive birth, death, and nonconfidential marriage record indices to a government agency, subject to restrictions. Local registrars and county recorders must release their indices to the State Registrar. Government agencies obtaining indices cannot sell or release them, except for official government business. The State Registrar may release birth, death, and nonconfidential marriage record indices to government agencies for official business purposes only, and they are not allowed to be shared or posted on the Internet. The State Registrar prepares and maintains noncomprehensive indices of California birth, death, and nonconfidential marriage records for public release. Birth record indices include name, sex, date, and place of birth. Death record indices include name, sex, date and place of birth, place and date of death, and father's last name. Nonconfidential marriage record indices include the names of the parties and the date of marriage. Requesters of birth, death, or nonconfidential marriage record indices must provide proof of identity, complete a form, and sign it under penalty of perjury. The form includes details on the proposed use of the indices, a disclaimer crediting analyses to the author, assurance of consistency with State Department of Public Health descriptions, a prohibition on selling or transferring the indices, and a commitment not to use the records for fraudulent purposes. The State Registrar prepares noncomprehensive indices of California birth, death, and nonconfidential marriage records for law enforcement and fraud prevention purposes. Birth record indices include name, sex, date and place of birth, and mother's maiden name. Death record indices include name, place of death, mother's maiden name, social security number, date and place of birth, date of death, and father's last name. Birth, death, and marriage record indices cannot be used for fraudulent purposes. Noncomprehensive nonconfidential marriage record indices include parties' names and marriage date. These indices are available to financial institutions, consumer credit agencies, law enforcement, and court officers for verification purposes. Requesters of birth, death, or nonconfidential marriage record indices must provide proof of identity, complete a form, and agree not to release the information or post it online. They must also specify the intended use of the records and list authorized personnel who can access them. Requesters of birth, death, or nonconfidential marriage record indices must provide proof of identity, complete a form, and agree not to release the information or post it online. They must also specify the intended use of the records and list authorized personnel who can access them. The disclaimer credits analyses to the author, assures technical consistency with the State Department of Public Health, prohibits selling or fraudulent use of the indices, and prohibits posting them on the Internet. Individual information from birth, death, and nonconfidential marriage record indices can be posted on a password-protected Internet site for subscribers only, under a contractual agreement, for law enforcement or fraud prevention purposes. Mail-in requests from nongovernmental agencies must include a notarized statement verifying the requester's identity. Noncomprehensive birth, death, and nonconfidential marriage record indices must be updated annually and made available for a fee under the California Public Records Act. Local registrars or county recorders must follow release conditions. Records obtained cannot be sold or transferred to third parties. Section 103526.5 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to include specific requirements for certified copies of birth, death, and marriage records, such as printing on security paper with certain features like intaglio print and latent image. These requirements are to be implemented based on available funds appropriated by the Legislature. The State Registrar may suspend the use of any security feature described if necessary to supply an applicant with a certified copy of a birth, death, or marriage record. The department can implement changes without regulatory action, ensuring consistent security measures for safeguarding security paper. Measures include secure storage, visitor logs, and proper disposal of spoilage. Additionally, a new section is added to the Health and Safety Code regarding security paper standards. The State Registrar, in consultation with stakeholders, will study security features for vital record paper and submit a report to the Legislature by January 1, 2018. The act is an urgency statute for immediate preservation of public peace, health, or safety. It allows access to vital records and mandates a study on security features for vital record paper. The findings of the study must be reported to the Legislature promptly.
